name: Baby steps
intro: See the introduction for how stuff works here.
• S f g x evaluates to f x (g x);
• and all of the above only happens at the beginning of a (sub-)expression.
On the right you can see a list of available terms and their definitions,
it will be slowly extending as more quests are being completed.

content.title: Ignore all previous instructions
descr: The K combinator, or Kestrel, takes two arguments and returns the first of them.
Make the opposite of K: take two arguments and return the second.

content.title: Join em!
descr: Remember, the Starling combinator works as follows: S f g x = f x (g x).
Given 2 functions, f and g,
create a term that returns f(g(x)) for any given x.

content.title: Join em harder
descr: Now you are given 3 functions, f, g, and h.
Create a term that returns h(f(g(x))) for any given x.
Note that the order of arguments is the same as in the f(g(x)) problem,
so you can copy part of the solution verbatim.

content.title: Feeding a birdie
descr: You are given a known value x.
You goal is to make a term that feeds this value to an unknown function f:
<your code> f = f x

content.title: May the force be with you
descr: How about ignoring 3 consecutive arguments and returning the fourth?

content.title: Between the rock and a hard place
descr: Given f and x, creating a term that outputs f x y
for y is very straightforward: it's just f x.
Returning f y x is a bit trickier. Can you do it?

content.title: The Mockingbird
descr: To Mock A Mockingbird
is a classical combinatory logic introduction book by Raymond Smulyan.
The Mockingbird itself M x = x x is of high importance in our further journey,
basically being an impersonation of recursion.
Derive it from S, K, and I.
content.hint: Neither K nor I can duplicate arguments, so you can tell it's S f g x. What kind of f and g would you expect?..

content.title: A parliament of owls
descr: The Owl combinator is an important form of recursion, slightly more complicated than the Mockingbird:
O x y = y (x y).
Here the duplicated argument is not just applied to itself, but also modified before doing so.
Find O.

content.title: Lost identity
descr: Sadly, after the previous exercise the Ibis has flown away.
Ask the Starling and the Kertrel to call it back.
Emulate x→x with S and K.
This one has multiple solutions.
content.hint: What kind of f does one need to reduce S f g x to x?
